snippet.title: Fulwood's Spinning Bullets in pursuit of finals berth
snippet.content: WHEELCHAIR BASKETBALL: Jake Fulwood's Queensland Spinning Bullets are shaping up for a final-round clash with Adelaide Thunderbirds in the National Wheelchair Basketball League. The team's fourth after 15 games and with only four teams making play-offs, it looms as a crucial clash in South Australia on Saturday. Fulwood, 22, has played 12 matches for the team during a stellar season, averaging more than eight points per outing. The Mooloolah Valley prospect played a key role for the Australian team at the under-23 world championships in Canada in June, when the team captured bronze. He was player-of-the-match in an overtime win over Italy during that tournament. Also a member of the Suncoast Spinners Wheelchair Basketball team (University of the Sunshine Coast), the Matthew Flinders Anglican product has spina bifida. He's had more than 15 major operations but they've hardly dented his determination. A regular on the representative scene, since he started playing basketball at 10 years of age, Fulwood's been invited to train with the Australian men's team the Rollers. He's also a university student. Steven Elliott was also part of the national team which fared well at Toronto and as a result he was recently named Gympie's latest Sunshine Coast Sports Federation development winner for June. "The talent of some of the guys over there was crazy," he said. "The way they were moving the chair was unbelievable." He said the world titles experience had fuelled his Paralympic dream. "It definitely inspired me," he said.
